RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 10th August 2018 - Turkish lira suffers meltdown, contagion fears hit risky assets
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • SNAP-SHOT: Lira smashed, Equities down, Treasuries up, crude up, dollar up.
  • REAR-VIEW: TRY down ~20%, Trump doubles up tariffs on Turkey, UK GDP inline, US Core CPI fresh cycle high, Canadian Employment Change beat.
  • NEXT WEEK: Chinese Industrial Output and Retail Sales, German GDP Flash, UK Jobs data, German ZEW Survey, Home Depot Earnings, UK CPI, US Retail Sales, Australian Jobs data, Norges Bank Interest Rate Decision, earnings from WMT, CSCO, HD, EZ and Canadian CPI, University of Michigan Sentiment.

* TURKEY: The TRY has been sliding since early European hours on Friday after the ECB expressed concerns on the effects of a weak Turkish currency on European banks and continued to slide as the Turkish President Erdogan speech did not abate economic fears and he instead called for repatriation of USD and gold. The TRY hit new record lows and was down over 20% at one stage, after US President Trump announced that he would be doubling up on tariffs on steel at 50% and aluminium at 20%. In response to the US move, the Turkish Foreign Ministry announced they would retaliate as necessary to the new tariffs. Following Friday’s TRY depreciation a  spokesperson the IMF stated they have received no indication from Turkish authorities that they are contemplating a request for financial assistance. Heading towards the weekend. US President Trump’s Lawyer Sekulow announced they are close to reaching an agreement on Pastor Brunson which in a slightly delayed reaction saw riskier assets catch a bid from their lows and safe haven assets saw the opposite.  
 
* GEOPOLITICS: RIA reported on Friday that Russia’s President Putin and the security council discussed possible sanctions on the US. This came after Russia's PM Medvedev said they would have to respond economically, politically or by other means to the new US sanctions. Following the US tariff announcement on Turkey, Turkish President Erdogan spoke with Russian President Putin on economic ties and announced they are pleased with the direction of the TurkishRussian trade relations. 
 
* US CPI: CPI MM ticked up by 0.2% from 0.1% seen in June meeting expectations, though the increase was only enough to keep the YY headline to 2.9%, consensus was at 3%; this remains the fastest rate in six years. The yearly figure remained unchanged mainly because of energy prices which have edged lower in the last two months and were down 0.5% in July. In contrast, Core CPI surprised to the upside and hit a fresh cycle high, with headline YY rising to 2.4% from 2.3%, beating expectations. Ex-food and energy prices in July continued their ascent, increasing 0.2% mostly on the back of higher new and used car prices. Analysts at Wells Fargo expect headline inflation to ease in the coming months as oil prices retreat but Core inflation to remain close to the current level as they see willingness from firms to raise prices; this should ‘keep the Fed on track to raise rates in September and most likely again in December.’  
 
* CANADIAN EMPLOYMENT CHANGE: The employment change for July came in strong posting an increase of 54.1k jobs, consensus was for a 17k rise. Nonetheless, the breakdown  was weak, where a full time employment fell by 28k and part time employment increased by 82k. Average Hourly Wages fell from June, to 3.0% from 3.5%.  
 
* SPX -0.71% at 2833, NDX -0.79% at 7408, DJI -0.77% at 25313. SECTORS: Energy +0.26%, Materials -1.43%, Industrials -0.81% Cons Discretionary -0.82%, Cons Staples 0.32%, Healthcare -0.39%, Financials -1.16%, Tech -0.81%, Telecoms -0.75%, Utilities -0.41%. 
 
* FUTURES: US futures followed on from the selloff in European equities amid the ongoing concerns in Turkey, which saw the Nasdaq snap its 8th daily consecutive gain. However the morning sell off in the US futures complex  calmed down but stocks were further pressured as Turkey announced they will retaliate as necessary to the ‘doubling’ tariffs,  extending losses to just shy of 1% before the near agreement on Pastor Brunson was announced which saw a small reversal.  
 
* EARNINGS: Microchip (MCHP) beat on EPS and revenues fell in line with expectations, however the co. provided forecasts for its next quarter revenue which was lower than the street’s estimates. Also, the CEO of the co. said the excessive Microsemi (MSCC) inventory is a headwind for revenue in the next couple of quarters. Dropbox (DBX) were also lower after their earnings report despite beats and raising guidance, which initially saw the stock higher pre-market but as they announced  they are to bring forward the lock up change to August 23rd from September 18th, gains were lost and extended to losses of ~8%.   
 
* Stock Specifics: Tesla’s (TSLA) board is said to meet with banks next week to analyse the going private proposal where funding will be addressed. Elsewhere, Pershing Square’s Bill Ackman sees substantial upside for Lowe’s (LOW) under the new CEO of the company, Marvin Ellison.  
 
* M&A: Cigna (CI) issued yet another letter showing  further support for the deal with Express Scripts (ESRX), which was also backed by ISS who also urged shareholders to vote in favour of the deal. 
 
* WTI CRUDE FUTURES (U8) SETTLE 82c HIGHER AT USD 67.63; BRENT CRUDE FUTURES (V8) SETTLE 74c HIGHER AT USD 72.81 
 
As crude markets slightly recovered yesterday from the prior day’s sell off, the rebound carried over into Friday’s session where Citi noted “The gains certainly make a bullish statement considering that weaker equities and a stronger US dollar would normally result in some risk-off selling across the broader commodity space.” News flow was relatively light again today apart from the ongoing geopolitical tensions, and the IEA report where they forecast oil demand growth for 2018 to rise 110kBPD to a total of 1.49mln BPD, and saw risks to 

 oil demand growth in 2019 due to trade disputes and rising prices if oil supply is constrained. Baker Hughes rig counts added the most oil rigs since may, oil was up 10 to 869 rigs, natgas rose 3 to 186 bringing the total to 1057 this week. 
 
* US 10YR T-NOTES SETTLE  21 TICKS HIGHER AT 120-12.  
 
Treasuries rallied throughout the day, with yields falling to a 3week low at one point, as risk-aversion spurred by the currency crisis in Turkey shifted investors’ position away from risky assets into a bid for safe-havens. Amid decent volume, the short end of the curve was hit more than the long end; 5yr yields were lower by c.7bps and 30yr yields were lower by c.6bps.The 10yr yield posted the biggest one-day fall since late May, hitting a low of 2.85%. 2s5s narrowed by c2.5bps, 2s10 by c.2bps, whilst 5s30 widened by c.1.5bps.  
 
* WEEKLY FX WRAP:  
 
* DXY: Another bullish weak for the broad Dollar and index as a bi-product, as all bar the safest of G10 havens suffer severe contagion from the EM exodus that reached fully-fledged FTQ status on Friday. In short, USD/pairings plummeted as the LIRA and ROUBLE continued to collapse to the point of capitulation for the Try that lost 20% at one stage on the final day of the week, having succumbed to a circa 10% dump late Tuesday/early Wednesday. In extremely fast market conditions, USDTRY got close to 7.0000 or 6.8000+ at least with only fleeting respite from rousing rhetoric from Turkish President Erdogan and his Finance Minister, but crucially no actual action. However, the final straw came from US President Trump who promptly doubled import tariffs on steel and aluminium from Turkey. Meanwhile, USDRUB has rallied to 67.6535 vs 63.3450 at the start of the week. Back to the DXY, 96.000 has been cleared to a fresh ytd peak at 96.313, and chart-watchers will now be eyeing 96.512 resistance ahead of a couple more upside tech levels before 97.000. 
 
* AUD, EUR: Friday’s major fall guys, but also among the worst non-EM performers over the week with some downbeat data and dovish RBA/ECB impulses (former via the policy meeting, commentary and SOMP, and latter from the latest bulletin) compounding the aforementioned risk-averse flows. AUDUSD has retreated sharply from just above 0.7450 to sub0.7300, while EURUSD finally breached strong support at the previous 2018 base to take about barriers and trip mega-stops to almost test 1.1400, while sliding through 1.1400 to 1.1350 vs the CHF. 
 
* GBP: Another big loser on a mix of ongoing Brexit jitters/uncertainty, political upheaval and BoE policy perceptions as ‘no deal’ prospects increased. Cable has tumbled from just over 1.3000 to circa 1.2725 and new ytd lows, but clawed back some lost ground vs the EUR as TRY woes hit the single currency harder to trade around 0.8950 vs 0.9030 at one stage, with the aid of some encouraging UK data (preliminary Q2 GDP, June trade and industrial output, plus a 0.5% NIESR forecast for Q3 growth). 
 
* CAD, NZD: Another crazy week for the Loonie in terms of volatility amidst better NAFTA news and mixed data, but mainly on an escalation in tensions between Canada and Saudi Arabia, with the latter instructing investors to liquidate Canadian assets and suspending other projects on top of diplomatic measures. USDCAD is mid-range between 1.31201.2955 trading parameters, with a degree of support from the latest jobs report revealing a big headline payroll beat, but not so upbeat internals. Returning down under, the Kiwi was significantly undermined by the RBNZ that trimmed OCR forecasts out to the end of 2019 and added that while the next move could go either way, rate cut chances have risen. This, along with overall themes leaves USDNZD hovering around 0.6600 vs 0.6761 at best and 0.6568 at worst, while the AUDNZD cross reached 1.1175 at one stage vs 1.1060 currently and 1.0950 or thereabouts at the beginning of the week. 
 
* JPY: The exception to the rule and only G10 to end the week on the up vs the USD and other currency counterparts as the effects of BoJ policy tweaks under the guise of flexibility continued to reverberate and stronger the anticipated Japanese GDP data exacerbated the JPY’s allure in times of aversion to risk/safety flights. Indeed, USDJPY is back below 111.00 following some choppy moves amidst huge option expiry interests layered between the big figure and 112.00. 
 
* SCANDI, EM: Even though firmer than forecast Swedish and Norwegian inflation data provided some protection for the SEK, and NOK especially, weak services metrics hampered the former and risk aversion in general prevented the latter from getting too carried away ahead of next week’s Norges Bank policy meeting. 
 
* NEXT WEEK:  Monday: No tier 1 data or notable events Tuesday: Chinese Industrial Output and Retail Sales, German GDP Flash, UK Jobs data, German ZEW Survey, Home Depot Earnings Wednesday: UK CPI, US Retail Sales, Cisco Earnings Thursday: Australian Jobs data, Norges Bank Interest Rate Decision, Walmart Earnings Friday: EZ and Canadian CPI, University of Michigan Sentiment. For the full RANsquawk Week in Focus click here.

Friday’s major fall guys, but also among the worst non-EM performers over the week with some downbeat data and dovish RBA/ECB impulses (former via the policy meeting, commentary and SOMP, and latter from the latest bulletin) compounding the aforementioned risk-averse flows. subject: RANsquawk Daily US Equity Opening News - 10th August 2018 - Tesla's (TSLA) board is set to meet with financial advisors next week to analyse the proposal made by CEO Elon Musk for Tesla to go private
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

10th August 2018

Earnings

  • Acxiom (ACXM) Q1 Adj. EPS USD 0.24 vs. Exp. 0.18, revenue USD 0.227bln vs. Exp. USD 0.220bln. (Newswires)
  • Applied Industrial Technologies Q4 EPS USD 1.03 vs. Exp. USD 1.00, revenue USD 0.897bln vs. Exp. USD 0.883bln. (Newswires)
  • DropBox (DBX) Q2 EPS 0.11 vs. Exp. USD 0.07, revenue USD 0.339bln vs. Exp. USD 0.330bln. Raises Q3 revenue guidance, sees FY18 revenue USD 1.366bln - 1.372bln vs. Exp. 1.36bln. COO Dennis Woodside to step down. (Newswires)
  • Lionsgate (LGF.A, LGF.B) Q1 Adj. EPS USD 0.18, vs. Exp. Loss/shr of USD 0.07, revenue USD 0.932bln vs. Exp. USD 0.885bln. Starz reported an increase of 300,000 subscribers in Q1 and announced to launch STRZPLAY channel in France, Italy, Spain in addition to UK and Germany. (Newswires)
  • Microchip Technology Inc (MCHP) Q1 EPS USD 1.61 vs. Exp. USD 1.48, revenue USD 1.21bln vs. Exp. USD 1.21bln. Forecasts Q2 EPS between USD 1.65 – 1.83 vs Exp. USD 1.69, revenue USD 1.474bln – 1.55bln vs Exp. USD 1.58bln. (Newswires)
  • News Corp (NWS) Q2 EPS USD 0.08 vs. Exp. USD 0.06, revenue USD 2.69bln vs. Exp. USD 2.65bln. (Newswires)
  • Trade Desk (TTD) Q2 EPS USD 0.60 vs. Exp. USD 0.44, revenue USD 0.112bln vs. Exp. USD 0.104. (Newswires)
  • Universal Display (OLED) Q2 Adj. EPS 0.23 vs. Exp. USD, 0.15, revenue USD 56.1mln vs. Exp. USD 49.58mln. (Newswires)

DJIA

  • Apple (AAPL) – The tech giant will enable customers to purchase new devices on the website using a ‘trade-in’ service which immediately offsets the cost and adds instant credit towards the new device. This comes ahead of the new iPhone release. Separately, Doug Field, vice president of engineering at Tesla (TSLA), is returning to Apple to work alongside executive Bob Mansfield on the self-driving car project. (9to5Mac/Newswires)
  • Exxon Mobil (XOM) – The oil group has entered into a contract with Kinder Morgan (KMI), EagleClaw and Apache (APA) to support the Permian pipeline project worth approx. USD 2bln. (Newswires)
  • JPMorgan (JPM) – CIO Lori Beer says the Wall Street bank has revamped its entry level tech programs in its ongoing war to compete for talent against Silicon Valley. (Newswires)
  • Microsoft (MSFT) – The tech giant threatened to expel far-right social network off its cloud. (Business Insider)
  • Walmart (WMT) – The co. and JD.com (JD) are investing USD 500mln in China’s logistics service to accelerate growth across the delivery network. (Newswires)

S&P500

  • Cognizant (CTSH) – The co. is to add 500 new technology jobs in Arizona as it launches its newest technology and service delivery centre in Mesa. (Newswires)
  • Express Scripts (ESRX)/Cigna (CI) – Cigna issued a letter expressing continued support for the proposed merger with Express Scripts (ESRX). ISS also recommends Cigna shareholders to vote in favour of the deal. (Newswires)
  • Ford (F) – The automaker reports July China sales down by 32% compared to July last year, to 57,662 vehicles adding to its worst year in China since it began operating there in 2001. (Newswires)
  • Lowe’s (LOW) - Pershing Square's Bill Ackman sees substantial upside for the co. under new CEO Marvin Ellison as he expects him to release the plan to renovate the co. in December. (Newswires)
  • Target (TGT) – The co. elects John Bauer as senior vice president, global inventory management. (Newswires)

NASDAQ 100

  • Amazon (AMZN) - UK Finance Minister Hammond says they are considering an ‘Amazon (AMZN)’ tax for online retailers. (Sky News)
  • DISH (DISH) – CFO is to resign and Paul W. Orban to succeed; effective August 22nd; according to a filing. (Newswires)
  • Qualcomm (QCOM) – The mobile chipmaker has reached a settlement with Taiwanese regulators after accusations the co. unfairly favoured Apple (AAPL). The USD 778 million fine will be replaced with a USD 93 million fine and USD 700 million invested in Taiwan over five years. (Newswires)
  • Tesla (TSLA) – The automaker’s board is set to meet with financial advisors next week to analyse the proposal made by CEO Elon Musk for Tesla to go private at USD 420/shr; according to people familiar with the matter. The board is likely to ask the CEO to recuse himself from the going private process and stated the CEO has ‘addressed the funding’. (CNBC)

OTHER NEWS

  • Alibaba (BABA) – The co. is investing USD 600mln in AI start-up Megvii. (Newswires)
  • Athenahealth (ATHN) – UnitedHealth (UNH) is among the potential buyers participating in the second round of bidding for the co.; according to three sources. (Dealreporter)
  • FactSet (FDS) – The co. announced to have won the lawsuit made by Ashbury Heights over a breach of contract and possible fraud. (Newswires)
  • JetBlue (JBLU) - Reports July traffic up 6.2%. (Newswires)
  • Overstock (OSTK) – GSR Capital, a PE firm in Hong Kong, is purchasing shares in the online retailer, as well as its blockchain subsidiary tZero. (CNBC)
  • Rite Aid (RAD) – After investors blocked the USD 24bln merger deal with Albertsons and are now relying on executive to come up with a new strategy to compete in the fast-moving retail industry. (WSJ)
  • Sprint (S) – The co. is to offer a lease on Apple’s (AAPL) iPhone X for USD 5/month with the deal beginning on August 10th. (Newswires)
  • Symantec (SYMC) – The co. filed to delay its earnings report due to it not having completed a previously announced internal investigation of its accounting practices. (CNBC)
  • Weight Watchers (WTW) – The co. has elected Julie Rice, who is a partner at We-Work and cofounder of SoulCycle, to the board of directors. (Newswires)
  • VMware (VMW) – The co. entered into a definitive agreement to acquire Dell EMC Service Assurance Suite. (Newswires)

Downgrades

subject: PRIMER: US CPI reading for July due on Friday 10th August 2018 at 1330BST/0830CDT
content:
Although Thursday’s PPIs surprised to the downside, dragged lower by softer services’ prices, the CPI release due on Friday is anticipated to come in strong. Expectations for headline CPI are for an increase of 0.2% M/M, which would bring the Y/Y figure to 3.0%; RBC notes that some mean reversion would suggest a more significant contribution to inflation is in the offing this month as shelter prices rose just 0.1% in June. The core measure is expected to remain steady at 2.3% Y/Y, the highest since the beginning of 2017.

Scotiabank expects this to be ‘the strongest reading since the end of 2011’ supported by base effects and elevated oil prices. Nevertheless gasoline prices saw a modest decline of 1% in July which may subtract from the headline figure, analysts at RBC say. Since the economy is robust and advancing at a strong GDP rate of 4.1%, the sustained growth is likely to place further pressure on prices which could lead inflation to ‘mildly overshoot the Fed target’, analysts at Barclays note. Further upside risks, of cost-push nature, may originate from the recent escalation of trade tariffs between US and China, with the latest seeing China’s implementation of 15% tariff on USD 16bln imports in response to US levies.

Overall the CPI release should keep the Fed on track for another hike in September given the robust economic conditions in the US, BMO argues. In terms of longer term outlook, CIBC states ‘there is no reason for the Fed for accelerate its rate hike path.’

content:

To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Reports of ECB concerns about European banks’ Turkish holdings slam the TRY to record lows
  • EUR, European equities struggling as investors take flight to safe haven assets
  • Looking ahead, highlights include, new Turkish economic model, US CPI and Canadian jobs

ASIA

Asian equity markets were mostly negative with sentiment subdued after a lacklustre lead from Wall St. where weakness in energy and financials dragged the DJIA and S&P 500, while the Nasdaq just about remained afloat to notch its 8th consecutive gain. ASX 200 (-0.3%) and Nikkei 225 (-1.3%) were lower with Australia weighed by weakness in energy stocks, while Tokyo trade failed to benefit from stronger than expected GDP amid a firmer currency. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (flat) and Hang Seng (-0.8%) traded choppy amid a lack of fresh drivers and after the PBoC refrained from operations again for a neutral position for the week. Finally, 10yr JGBs were higher with demand spurred by losses in riskier assets and with the BoJ also present in the market for nearly JPY 800bln in JGBs.

PBoC skipped open market operations and were net neutral for the week vs. last week's CNY 210bln net drain. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8395 (Prev. 6.8317)

Japanese GDP (Q2) Q/Q 0.5% vs. Exp. 0.3% (Prev. -0.2%). (Newswires)

Japanese GDP Annualised (Q2) 1.9% vs. Exp. 1.4% (Prev. -0.6%, Rev. -0.9%)

EU/UK/US

ECB concerns are said to be increasing regarding EU banks' exposure to Turkey amid a slump in TRY. (FT)

UK GDP Prelim QQ Q2 0.4% vs. Exp. 0.4% (Prev. 0.2%)

UK GDP Prelim YY Q2 1.3% vs. Exp. 1.3% (Prev. 1.2%)

UK Industrial Output MM Jun 0.4% vs. Exp. 0.4% (Prev. -0.4%, Rev. -0.2%)

UK Industrial Output YY Jun 1.1% vs. Exp. 0.7% (Prev. 0.8%, Rev. 1.2%)

UK Manufacturing Output MM Jun 0.4% vs. Exp. 0.3% (Prev. 0.4%, Rev. 0.6%)

UK Manufacturing Output YY Jun 1.5% vs. Exp. 1.0% (Prev. 1.1%, Rev. 1.5%)

Norwegian CPI MM Jul 0.7% vs. Exp. 0.3% (Prev. 0.6%)

Norwegian CPI YY Jul 3.0% vs. Exp. 2.6% (Prev. 2.6%)

Swedish CPI MM Jul 0.5% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. 0.2%)

Swedish CPI YY Jul 2.1% vs. Exp. 2.0% (Prev. 2.1%)

GEOPOLITICAL

Satellite images suggested that North Korea is continuing work on a secondary cooling system at its 5MWe reactor, according to 38 North. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European equities have started the day negative (Euro Stoxx 50 -1.4%) as reports suggest the ECB is expressing concerns of a weak TRY on European banks. This is pressuring European banks as a whole (STOXX® Europe 600 Banks (SX7P) -1.7%) as investors are repositioning into safe-haven assets and away from the financial sector, which is the current sector underperformer. BNP Paribas (-3.7%), BBVA (-3.3%) and UniCredit (-3.1%) are bringing up the rear of the Stoxx 600 on the back of high exposure to Turkish assets.

FIXED INCOME

No surprise to see UK debt and STIR futures correct higher (bar the very front end of the curve) given confirmation of a weak start in EU stocks and the ongoing, albeit not so intense as it was pre-Liffe, Try-inspired safety flight. Gilts gapped up to 123.45 from yesterday’s 123.02 settlement level, so above ‘strong’ technical resistance around 123.39 from the off, and have advanced further to 123.53 for a 51 tick gain on the day before topping out, but Bunds have marginally extended their upside on Eurex to 163.13 (+63 ticks) with a bit more premium due to the latest decline in BTPs perhaps. Back to Liffe, 3 month contracts are still factoring ‘dovish’ BoE policy guidance and building in potential for a reversal of the latest rate hike on rising Brexit no deal risks. Note the raft of heavyweight UK data, including preliminary Q2 GDP, June ip, manufacturing and construction output, was mixed or close to consensus and had little impact. Turning to US Treasuries, firmer and flatter not far from overnight session highs on broad risk-aversion and ahead of potentially key data in the form of CPI.

FX

TRY - Almost relentless selling early Friday, to the point of a full-on capital flight at one stage, saw the Lira collapse to new all time lows vs the Usd with vendors and price feeds quoting levels for the pair anywhere between 6.0000-50 in fast, if not frantic market conditions. However, some respite for the Try ahead of and after Turkish current account data that was slightly better than forecast in the event, but the focus now very much on speeches from President Erdogan (midday and 14.30BST), and more importantly the Finance Minister’s new economic model (12.30BST). Usd/Try back under 6.0000, but only just.

DXY - The index is just off best levels, but riding high near fresh 2018 peaks around 96.182 and still over the big figure amidst widespread Dollar gains, bar vs the safest of safe-haven currencies, Jpy as the aforementioned Lira and EM meltdown spills over to majors. Technically, 96.512 is next on the radar, assuming no intervention to stop the rout and/or a major upset for the Greenback independently (weak CPI data?).

JPY - As noted, the exception to the rule, as Usd/Jpy trades mostly below 111.00 on risk-off positioning and the Jpy is also boosted by stronger than forecast Japanese GDP data overnight. Chart-wise, 110.53 represents nearest support and bids/stops are likely situated around 110.50.

CHF - Holding up better than other G10s vs the Usd circa mid-range between 0.9975-30, but forging more gains relative to the Eur just through 1.1400 as the single currency suffers from Try contagion and warnings from the ECB about Euro area banks that are especially exposed to Turkey.

AUD/EUR/GBP/CAD/NZD - It’s a list, and ordered by performance from worst hit to not quite so badly affected for all the well documented reasons ranging from ongoing trade wars, diplomatic sanctions and implications for the global economy/Central bank policy. Aud/Usd has slipped under 0.7300 as the YUAN loses recovery momentum, Eur/Usd tumbled through 1.1500 unceremoniously as barriers broke and stops were triggered and Cable caved through 1.2800 with little aid from mixed UK data, while the Loonie is back below 1.3100 vs its US rival ahead of Canadian jobs data. The Kiwi has lost grip of 0.6600, but holding up better than its antipodean counterpart as the cross slips back below 1.1100 from 1.1175 highs.

RUB/SEK/NOK - Also victims of the latest deterioration in sentiment, with the Rouble rout squeezing Usd/Rub up beyond 67.0000 before a modest pull-back, while the Scandi crowns are somewhat mixed after inflation data revealing bigger upside vs expectations from Norway compared to Sweden. Eur/Sek midway between 10.3580-4615 parameters, but Eur/Nok hugging the base of a 9.5410-5940 band.

COMMODITIES

Oil is set for its 6th weekly loss as the crude complex is being hit by a rising USD, and risk aversion with both WTI and Brent down ~0.8% on the day, and Brent set for a near 2% and WTI looking at a near 3% fall for the week.

In the metals complex, gold is down and straddling the USD 1210/oz level, as the rising dollar is hitting the gold market, which is looking at its 5th consecutive weekly fall. Copper has given up gains seen in early trade and is currently down 1.1% as an 11.3% fall in copper inventories seen by ShFE over the past week has not counteracted the USD hitting 13 month highs. Aluminium is also down 0.5% on the day.

IEA raise their 2018 oil demand growth forecast by 110k BPD to 1.49mln BPD, and see risks to 2019 oil demand growth from trade disputes and rising prices if supply is constrained

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 10th August 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian equity markets were mostly negative with sentiment subdued after a lacklustre lead from Wall St.
  • Heading into European trade, EUR/USD tripped stops on a break of 1.1500 to the downside to print its weakest level in around a year
  • Looking ahead, highlights include UK GDP and output, US CPI and Canadian jobs

ASIA

Asian equity markets were mostly negative with sentiment subdued after a lacklustre lead from Wall St. where weakness in energy and financials dragged the DJIA and S&P 500, while the Nasdaq just about remained afloat to notch its 8th consecutive gain. ASX 200 (-0.1%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.7%) were lower with Australia weighed by weakness in energy stocks, while Tokyo trade failed to benefit from stronger than expected GDP amid a firmer currency. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) and Hang Seng (-0.4%) traded choppy amid a lack of fresh drivers and after the PBoC refrained from operations again for a neutral position for the week. Finally, 10yr JGBs were higher with demand spurred by losses in riskier assets and with the BoJ also present in the market for nearly JPY 800bln in JGBs. 

PBoC skipped open market operations and were net neutral for the week vs. last week's CNY 210bln net drain. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8395 (Prev. 6.8317)

Japanese GDP (Q2) Q/Q 0.5% vs. Exp. 0.3% (Prev. -0.2%). (Newswires)
Japanese GDP Annualised (Q2) 1.9% vs. Exp. 1.4% (Prev. -0.6%, Rev. -0.9%)


UK/EU

BoE’s McCafferty (Hawk) said UK wage growth to reach 4% next year, while he also stated the City was currently pencilling in two interest rate rises in the next two years but added that the increases would probably be “front-end loaded”. (Guardian)

US and EU have begun laying groundwork for a trade agreement with the State Department instructing EU embassies to source trade deliverables, while EU delegation is planning a Washington trip late this month. (Newswires)

ECB concerns are said to be increasing regarding EU banks' exposure to Turkey amid a slump in TRY. (FT)

One of out a hundred banks and building societies have passed on last week’s BoE rate hikes in full to its savers, causing anger from MPs and campaigners. HSBC and Barclays have raised cost of mortgages but left savers without any benefits (Times)


FX

In FX markets, the DXY was initially flat as it took a breather from yesterday’s gains against its major counterparts which kept EUR/USD and GBP/USD at the bottom halves of the 1.1500 and 1.2800 handles respectively, before EUR/USD then tripped stops on a break of 1.1500 to the downside to print its weakest level in around a year and which in-turn underpinned the greenback. Antipodeans were also subdued and failed to make any meaningful recovery from the recent descent in which NZD/USD tested 0.6600 to the downside in the wake of the dovish RBNZ, while AUD/USD languished after an unsurprising SOMP which reiterated the view for no near-term change in rates and lowered underlying inflation forecasts. Elsewhere, USD/JPY retreated below 111.00 and JPY-crosses extended on losses amid flows into JPY spurred by a risk averse tone and firmer than expected GDP numbers, while TRY continued to tumble and extended on fresh record lows amid the ongoing diplomatic spat related to the detained US pastor and as reports noted increasing concern at the ECB of banks’ exposure to Turkey.

RBA Statement on Monetary Policy reiterated that the board sees no strong case for a change in rates in the near-term and that higher rates are likely to be appropriate at some time if the economy evolves as forecast. In addition, the RBA maintained December 2018 GDP growth forecast at 3.25%, but trimmed December 2018 underlying CPI forecast to 1.75% from 2.00%. (Newswires)
 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were flat overnight with WTI crude futures range-bound below the USD 67.00/bbl and are still on course to post losses of around 2.50% for the week. Elsewhere, gold was also uneventful and remained near the prior day’s lows as the greenback remained firm, while copper mirrored the risk averse sentiment and lacklustre trade across the complex.

GEOPOLITICAL

Satellite images suggested that North Korea is continuing work on a secondary cooling system at its 5MWe reactor, according to 38 North. (Newswires)
 

US

The Treasury complex drifted higher on Thursday, with yields suppressed by unchanged PPI and ahead of the CPI release due tomorrow. The yield curve bull-flattened with yields hitting session lows following the 30yr auction; 5yr yields lower by c.3bps and the 30yr yield by c.4bps. The US sold $18bln in 30yr bonds tailing by 0.3bps at a high yield of 3.09%. The bid-to-cover posted at 2.27x, below the previous auction and the 6wk average, at the lowest level since February. In terms of internals, dealers were awarded the biggest share since February, indirects were awarded shares well above the trendline whilst directs took the smallest portion since January. US 10YR T-notes settled 7 ticks higher at 119-23.

Fed’s Evans (Non-Voter, Dove) said the US economy is performing ‘very well’ and that one or two more rate hikes is reasonable by the end of year. Evans also commented that fundamentals are ‘extremely strong’ with uncertainty surrounding trade offset by business confidence following tax cuts and moves towards deregulation, while he added that he now feels inflation has returned to near the 2% target and is likely to remain there.  Furthermore, Evans commented that debate over whether to pause or continue higher into restrictive policy to intensify the next year as they approach the neutral interest rate. (Newswires)

Mexico’s Economy Minister Guajardo said NAFTA talks are going well but there is no NAFTA deal yet while he added they are doing their best to get a NAFTA auto deal done as soon as possible. (Newswires)

Canada's ambassador to the US McNaughton said relations with the US are strong despite the tariffs and that an auto deal is getting close, but a sunset clause does remain a sticking point. (Newswires)

subject: ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia stocks are set to finish the week indecisive, with Japan failing to benefit from strong GDP data as a firmer JPY weighs
content:
Asia equity markets are mixed with the region indecisive after a lacklustre lead from Wall St. where weakness in energy and financials dragged the DJIA and S&P 500, while the Nasdaq just about remained afloat to notch its 8th consecutive gain. ASX 200 (-0.2%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.4%) are subdued with energy stocks weighing on Australia, while Tokyo trade fails to benefit from stronger than expected GDP numbers amid a firmer currency. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (+0.1%) and Hang Seng (-0.1%) are choppy amid a lack of fresh drivers and after the PBoC refrained from operations again for a neutral position for the week.

In FX markets, the DXY is relatively flat and takes a breather from yesterday’s gains against its major counterparts which has kept EUR/USD and GBP/USD at the lower halves of the 1.1500 and 1.2800 handles respectively. Antipodeans are also subdued and have failed to make any meaningful recovery from the recent descent with NZD/USD now testing 0.6600 to the downside in the wake of the dovish RBNZ, while AUD/USD languishes after an unsurprising SOMP which reiterated the board sees no strong case for a near-term change in rates and lowered underlying inflation forecasts. Elsewhere, USD/JPY retreated below 111.00 and JPY-crosses extended on losses, due to flows into JPY spurred by a risk averse tone in Tokyo and firmer than expected GDP numbers.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are higher as riskier assets in Tokyo are pressured, while the BoJ are also present in the market for nearly JPY 800bln in JGBs.
